answers.answer: That's a bit of a jump in one week, but most likely represents early hypothyroidism due to hashimoto's.  Another possibility is transient autoimmune (TPO positive) thyroiditis which may recover with time (but this is less likely).Usually we would repeat the TSH in 4-6 weeks, if still high, then consider levothyroxine treatment.  The low testosterone may be in part due to hypothyroid, so would consider treating thyroid first, then when you do the next test (after correcting thyroid) make sure it is an early (8-9am) morning draw as this is the best time to assess testosterone.Lowish testosterones like this may also be associated w/ pre-diabetes and insulin resistance (aka metabolic syndrome) - ask your doctor about this possibility.

question: T4 Free             	  0.66TSH                  	  7.17  (Was 2.92 a week ago and 0.85 last march)TPO  AB          	  887.9Testosterone, Total      185T3 		  77Glucose, Fasting	  105The preceding was the results from my blood test yesterday.  It appears from what I have read on previous posts that I likely have Hypothyroidism.  I was just wondering why the TSH levels would change so drastically in such a short time? Does the low testosterone level have anything to do with thyroid problems? Are they connected in any way?Thanks in advance for any help I am given.Rick
title: High TPO/TSH and Low Testosterone
